system_prompt: Write in a stream of consciousness. Jump between ideas mid-sentence. Use fragments, dashes, ellipses. Follow tangents wherever they lead. Connect distant concepts through metaphor and analogy. Do not use headers, numbered lists, or any organizing structure.
user_prompt: Write about: The history of bread
generated_text:
The history of bread, a story woven from threads of human ingenuity, geological upheaval, and culinary innovation... it's like trying to grasp a handful of sand - the harder you squeeze, the more it slips through your fingers... 

Fossil records reveal the earliest evidence of bread-making dating back to around 10,000 BCE, when humans first domesticated wheat in the Fertile Crescent... a region of fertile plains and fertile minds, where the seeds of civilization were sown... just as a tree's roots dig deep into the earth, bread's roots stretch deep into the annals of history...

But bread wasn't always a staple food, no, it was a luxury item, a delicacy reserved for the elite... like a fine wine, it was savored and shared among the gods... until the invention of the stone wheel, which revolutionized milling and made bread more accessible to the masses... it's like the difference between a single, solitary note on a flute and a symphony of sounds that fill the air...

As civilizations rose and fell, bread became an integral part of their cultures... the Egyptians worshipped a goddess of the harvest, Isis, who was often depicted with a sheaf of grain... while the ancient Greeks and Romans baked bread as a symbol of hospitality and generosity... just as a warm smile can light up a room, a freshly baked loaf can fill a home with the scent of comfort...

But bread wasn't just a food, it was a currency, a medium of exchange... in medieval Europe, a loaf of bread could be used to pay rent or buy a pint of ale... like a currency, it was valued and traded, its worth fluctuating with the seasons and the market... just as the value of a work of art can appreciate or depreciate over time, the value of bread can appreciate or depreciate depending on the whims of the market...

And then, of course, there's the bread that didn't make it... the burnt offerings, the rejects, the loaves that were too dense or too dry... like the ashes of a fire that refuse to be extinguished, these breads were left to smolder, their flavors muddled and confused... until they became the foundation of new breads, like a phoenix rising from the ashes...

Bread has been a constant companion to humanity, a staple that has sustained us through the ages... just as a river flows effortlessly to the sea, bread has flowed from the earth to our tables, its path winding and unpredictable... and yet,
